title: Social Machines + Knowledge Turning: A Big Question in Computation, Intelligence and Life

author: Carole Goble, School of Mathematics, University of Manchester

segmentation: So hello, I'm Carol goebel.
I'm a computer scientist at the University of Manchester, and I thought I'd give a little bit of context.
First to my my big question, 'cause it's a very egocentric question.
I'm hoping somebody in the audience will be able to answer.
So I build systems for scientists and my job is to use all these great knowledge technologies, AI technologies, distributed computing, social computing technologies.
In order to do 2 two tasks, improve knowledge.
Turning in science that is to be able to encourage scientists to actually collaborate and share.
Which is a thankless task because most scientists actually flirt rather than share.
But that's another story and enable the reproducibility of scientific artifacts.
And that's another thing that's a dirty secret.
The most science is in fact, not reproduce.
Reproducible at all.

That's another talk, but in order to be able to do this, I need to be able to create environments that allow us to collaborate and work with our scientists so that they are using tools and they are working together and they're working together in order to solve problems in ecological niche modeling.
The sickness of cattle in Africa, and so these are all my my areas.
This means that I've actually bumped against this particular problem.
The Turing test is putting a computer or human computer Anna machine.

An automatic computer is cheering, puts it on equal footing to convince a human that a machine is a human individual, and actually what I'm interested in, and I really would need help with, is serving a machine with a collective of humans acting as if they were computational entity.
So I need it the other way around.
Now the question is, I thought I mean well I put this beautifully in her earlier talk WHI emulator human to solve a complex task.

When you get get a bunch of humans to help you solve that complex cart task along with the machine and a weaker form which is to get many humans to collaborate together in order to be able to solve the particular task.
So I'm interested not so much in AI as in collective.
Intelligence, if you will, or universal social machine that we could define unreliably build.
That would combine humans and machines together in the same system.
Now this is actually what Tim Berners Lee puts says in his weaving the web book.
This is the intent.

Was that the web would be such a social machine where people would do the complex things and computers would do the really boring stuff as opposed to AI, which seems to be the computers deck to do the cool stuff.
As far as I can make out.
So the examples of this already you all use captures and recaptures the completely automated public Turing test to tell computers and humans apart.
And when you type in these two strings in order to be able to get to a particular site, you're actually helping to improve OCR encoding of books and there's about 200 million of these typed in a day.
So we're doing an awful lot of work in order to be able to do unknowingly.
Tasks of improving OCR of textbooks.
The latest one is this is Luis Von Arms.
Workers across a poster boy in this area of let's translate all the web into all languages by getting everybody else to do it by learning a language.
And as they learn the language, they translate the web.
So this is just started.
You can sign up so this isn't language translation by machine.
This is language translation by millions of people working today.

For a well known example is the fold it so this particular retroviral protease which had taken something like a decade to fail, to actually be structurally folded, took 10 days when given to a bunch of gamers.
In fact, given to 57,000 gamers, but gamers are free, I mean they were sitting in their basements doing nothing in the dark with their mothers shouting down to them.
Let's use them so, you know, that's what we should do, and that's what we do.
Let's exploit the.

And similarly, the Zoey verse, whole plethora of tools that have been developed to Oxford in order to be able to identify objects, objects in the Sky in this in the Sky surveys, they just finished a Galaxy Zoo two which was surveying particular objects in a Galaxy survey activity, and they had 60 million observations taken by 30,000 people.
And you wouldn't be able to gather that.
That kind of stuff and be able to solve that kind of image processing problem in a computational way in the time they go.
And a more mundane aspects.
Of course, Wikipedia or the Cyantific PD as the Amazon Turk that we use in order to collect gather information and my own tools.
I'd put one of my own tools in this as well, which is trying to get people to collaborate and and improve one another's work together.
So here's what I would like is a big challenge.
These social machines are being developed right now, but we have no idea what social computation really is weird.
These are all hacks.
They're all being developed, is is not engineering really.
It's not asserting not anything above craft and cookery.
We haven't really got a grasp on what this means to have people.

As part of the whole process of the program was the asynchronous and synchronous properties, where the theoretical foundations, empirical observations, the design and engineering practices, economic and business models, and so on.
This early work being done in Trento and in Edinburgh and in projects like Sockeye which is led by Tim Berners Lee.
But I think here we have a real opportunity to affect.
Reality fact real systems that really affect people and bring some rigor to this approach.
So thank you.
Thanks very much.
